maps.text: Un mapamundi que destaca los países Brasil, España y Portugal, lugares donde vivieron los personajes del texto.

common.text:
### Patronymics and Surnames

For a large part of the Middle Ages—a historical period encompassing European history between the years <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite0>)—in the region of the Iberian Peninsula (Portugal and Spain), surnames were not used as they are today. Instead, patronymics were employed, that is, names formed from the father's first name (<htcite1>).

Despite the fact that, today, we see different people using Dias as a surname, it is not possible to claim that they all belong to the same family, as we will see below.

#### The Patronymic

The origin of the surname Dias as a patronymic becomes evident when analyzing medieval documents. The "Corónica Navarra", for example, mentions Rodrigo Díaz, El Cid, as the son of Diego Laínez, grandson of Laín Núñez, and great-grandson of Nuño Laínez (<htcite2>; <htcite3>):

• "...Nuyno Laniz prisó muyller a don Elo, et ovo en eylla Layn Nunyz. Layn Nuniç ovo fijo a Iac Layniç. Diac Layniç prisó mujer fija de Roy Diaz Alvariz d’Esturias, et fo muyt bon ombre, et muy rico, et ovo en eylla a Rodric Diaç"

Similarly, when analyzing various Portuguese documents, Dr. José Augusto de Sotto Mayor Pizarro presents, in two of his works, several people who signed as Dias and who were the children of a man named Diogo (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

#### Surnames

The use of patronymics remained widespread in Portuguese society during the 14th century, according to the Gregorian calendar. In this period, it is possible to verify their use by over 90% of the Portuguese population (<htcite2>).

A significant transition is also observed in this context: patronymics like Dias, which initially indicated lineage, gradually began to be used as hereditary surnames (<htcite3>).

#### Consequences

The conversion of patronymics into surnames ended up creating a false idea of kinship between people who shared the same last name, leading many to believe they belonged to the same family. To give an idea, in old São Paulo de Piratininga, Américo de Moura identified ten distinct family groups using the surname Dias, with no relation to each other (<htcite4>).

Reflection 1: They would be equal if they weren't different

Have you ever in your life read or heard a text that considered people who were very different, separated by great distances, to be "the same" simply because they shared the same surname?

Before learning this information about patronymics and surnames, what was your opinion about that idea, or about the text that presented it?

history.text: Isabel Dias, wife of João Ramalho (<htcite0>), due to the period in which she lived, does not have much documentation about her. For this reason, it is necessary to make a separation between what we really know and what is supposed to have happened.

#### Name

Isabel Dias, a Christian name, is mentioned as a prominent indigenous woman in the Jesuit letters contemporary to her, according to modern interpretations of these letters (<htcite0>).

Later genealogies mention her as *Mbicy* or *Bartira* (<htcite1>). However, during the research for the preparation of this text, no document was found that confirms these names.

Given these facts, we will proceed only with her Christian baptismal name.

#### Daughter of ....

The name is not the only point that draws attention in later genealogies. They also state, categorically, that Isabel Dias is the daughter of the *“Indian chief Tevereçá or Tebeririçá”* (<htcite2>). This statement deserves reflection:

Reflection 2: How do you know that?

Generally, statements like those of Luiz G. Silva Leme tend to lead to conclusions, despite omitting important details.

On the other hand, accepting without question can create barriers to knowledge and lead to mistaken conclusions.

Given this scenario, how can there be an assertion that she was someone's daughter without presenting any proof?
A letter from Father Manuel da Nóbrega to Father Luiz Gonçalves da Câmara gives us a clue (<htcite0>):

• "João Ramalho is very well known and revered among the gentiles and has daughters married to the principal men of this Captaincy and all these sons and daughters are from one indigenous woman, daughter of the greatest and most principal men of this land."

It is observed that there is no mention of names, only of social positions.

Américo de Moura, commenting on the subject of Isabel Dias's paternity, mentions (<htcite0>):
• "She was the daughter of the principal of the village of Inhapuambuçú, who I believe was not TIBIRIÇÁ, but his father or uncle."

In favor of Américo de Moura's hypothesis, we have the following data:
- Tibiriçá died after Isabel Dias and is praised by São José de Anchieta, who mentions him as having *"so much sense and maturity that he did not seem like a man from Brazil"* (<htcite0>). Thus, it would be more likely to associate Isabel Dias with someone more aligned with the colonizers.
- João Mendes de Almeida, in a genealogical, linguistic, and geographical analysis, considers it illogical to regard Tibiriçá as the "headman". On the contrary, he mentions Piqueróbi as the great Tupi chief (<htcite1>).

We must emphasize that the conclusions of João M. de Almeida about one leader do not reflect a consensus. What is still accepted today is that, upon the arrival of the colonizers, the land was divided among three brothers: Piqueroby, Tibiriçá, and Caiubi. The indigenous people under Piqueroby's rule did not accept colonization, which resulted in a war in the year <htdate0> (<htcite2>).

Finally, given the lack of documents or chronicles that confirm any connection of Isabel Dias with a specific leader, we will consider Isabel Dias's father as unknown.

#### Her Life

About her life prior to the arrival of the Society of Jesus, nothing can be stated for certain. After its arrival, however, some data stand out — such as, for example, the Europeans' misunderstanding of indigenous family structures (<htcite0>; <htcite1>) which led them to report (<htcite2>):

• "In this land is one João Ramalho. He has been here for a very long time and his entire life and that of his sons conforms to that of the Indians and he is a petra scandali (stumbling block) for us, because his life is the main obstacle with the gentility we have, because he is very well known and very related to the Indians. They have many wives. He and his sons are with sisters and have children with them, both the father and the sons."

This description of having more than one wife contrasts strongly with the data from João Ramalho's will, in which only Isabel Dias is mentioned (<htcite0>). As a consequence, it becomes impossible to know exactly how many descendants of João Ramalho there are today.

Reflection 3: My children are…

Our children are our future — the continuation of the species.

If someone asked you to ignore or not document your children, what would you do?

The fact that her husband maintained a union with more than one indigenous woman resulted in his excommunication (<htcite0>; <htcite1>). This excommunication was later reversed, with João Ramalho being praised in another letter from Nóbrega to Father Luiz Gonçalves da Câmara and by Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite2>; <htcite3>).

One factor that may have contributed to the reversal was the commitment and alignment to Christianity of his wife, which is explicitly mentioned in a letter written just after her death (<htcite4>; <htcite5>).
Had a marriage with João Ramalho, as mentioned in her husband's will, dated <htdate0> (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).
According to a mention in his father's will (<htcite0>).

Her existence is unquestionable, given her mention, alongside her husband, in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>). On the other hand, this is one of the few certainties we have about her.

#### Name

Just like Isabel Dias, studied above, there is no source that allows us to state how she was identified among her indigenous relatives.

#### Daughter of...

Recent studies have helped us not to identify them, but rather to rule out possible parents attributed to Beatriz Dias by later genealogies.

Regarding the original understanding, Américo de Moura informs us (<htcite0>):
• "...with discrepancies in traditions and in the opinions of genealogists, she is supposedly the daughter of João Ramalho or of Tibiriçá"

Genetic results from ongoing research indicate that Beatriz Dias and Isabel Dias do not share the same mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) (<htcite0>). As a consequence, it is possible to rule out that she was the daughter of Isabel Dias, but not of João Ramalho, who had relationships with numerous women (<htcite1>). This genetic result confirms what is shown in João Ramalho's will (<htcite2>).

Similarly, Tibiriçá, as an indigenous person, would have followed the traditions of his people over European ideas of family—a fact that does not allow us to affirm that Beatriz was the daughter of Tibiriçá, nor of another indigenous person whose name we do not know.

Given this entire scenario, just like Américo de Moura, we present the relationship with João Ramalho and Tibiriçá only as hypothetical, considering her parents as unknown.

#### DNA and History

Mappings of mitochondrial DNA in matrilineal descendants (the female lineage of a person) help us understand connections between individuals, due to some characteristics of mtDNA:
- mtDNA is small in our species, containing only 16,500 base pairs responsible for 37 genes (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).
- The difference in the number of base pairs between us and other primate species is only about 100 pairs. This is because the base pair substitution rate is only 0.02 substitutions per million years (<htcite2>).
- This reduced rate of variation means there are only five haplogroups among indigenous American women (A, B, C, D and X), with only three out of every hundred indigenous women possessing haplogroup X (<htcite3>).

Precisely because of the few alterations—which are also synonymous with mutations and evolution—we can safely trace a person's origin, but not necessarily their lineage.

source.text: Brown, W. M., George Jr, M., & Wilson, A. C.
Lawless, C., Greaves, L., Reeve, A. K., Turnbull, D. M., & Vincent, A. E.
Brown, W. M., George Jr, M., & Wilson, A. C.
Brown, M. D., Hosseini, S. H., Torroni, A., Bandelt, H. J., Allen, J. C., Schurr, T. G., Scozzari, R., Cruciani, F., & Wallace, D. C.

(a) Mitochondrial DNA haplogroup composition of samples plotted at the site of the wastewater collection. Circle colors and colors of the pie charts correspond to specifc haplogroups, while colors of the underscores indicate the four broad biogeographic ancestry categories. (b) Mitochondrial DNA haplogroup composition of samples using only the four broad biogeographic ancestry categories. history.text:
Mathematics in History

Genetic tests help us validate or refute later genealogical proposals, but to use biology, it is also necessary to resort to mathematics.

An example of this is the size of our mitochondrial DNA and its organization. When we say that our mtDNA is grouped into base pairs, it means that when dividing the bases by two (pairs), the remainder is equal to zero (History Tracers Tream, , Is this extra?). That is, nature does not leave bases "left over" when grouping DNA.

This pairing does not occur by chance: DNA is formed by the bases adenine (A), cytosine (C), thymine (T) and guanine (G). They always pair in only one way—adenine with thymine (A–T) and guanine with cytosine (G–C) (Alberts B, Johnson A, Lewis J, et al., ).
The relationship is mentioned by her daughter in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>).
According to her words in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>).
According to his words in his inventory (<htcite0>).

The Dias (Machado) family, established in São Vicente, has its origins in Portugal (<htcite0>). However, it is not possible to determine precisely the region of their birth or the identity of the parents of the brothers Lopo Dias and Rui Dias Machado, who lived in São Vicente and São Paulo de Piratininga.

In addition to the unknown parentage, we also cannot determine, based on the data currently available, which of the brothers was the elder.

On the other hand, a notable aspect of this family’s history is their deep Christian faith, as will be demonstrated in the description of their members’ lives.
According to research, it is only possible to affirm that they had Portuguese origins, without being able to specify their exact birthplace (<htcite0>)
Nothing is known about this person. However, since two brothers traveled to Brazil, it is presumed that this individual must have existed within the family context.
The family was created because we found out that your brother also went to Brazil (<htcite0>).
The family was created because we found out that your brother also went to Brazil (<htcite0>).

Lopo Dias lived in Santo André between <htdate0> and <htdate1> (<htcite0>), and by <htdate2> he was already residing in São Paulo de Piratininga (<htcite1>).

He had a long life, as evidenced by his statement in his son’s estate inventory dated <htdate3> (<htcite2>):

• "I regret, honorable judges, excusing myself from being the guardian of my grandchildren, sons of Belchior Carneiro, for I am not ... able to be so, both because of my age and because I have joined ... the Carmelite fathers as their brother; therefore, they may appoint whomever they see fit as guardian, and I sign here today, January 1st, 609."

In addition to his explicit connection with the Carmelite Order, which even led to land donations to the Order (<htcite0>; <htcite1>; <htcite2>), Lopo Dias was also one of the signatories for the construction of the main church in the city of São Paulo (<htcite3>).

Centuries after his death, Lopo Dias was mistakenly identified as a Jew due to being a namesake of a Jewish individual (<htcite4>). However, this hypothesis has several inconsistencies:
- As stated in the introduction, there was not only one Dias family;
- Contemporary documents link him directly to the Carmelite Order and to the Church of São Paulo, showing his strong connection to the Christian faith;

- The name “Lopo” (or “Lubb”) was not exclusive to any one faith — Islamic families such as the Banu Qasi also used it — showing that the use of the name was not restricted to a single religious group (<htcite5>).

Therefore, his religious identity cannot be defined based solely on his name.

His descendants will be presented together with those of his wife, in respect for indigenous traditions (<htcite6>).
This relationship is mentioned by his daughter in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>).

He served as ordinary judge of São Vicente in <htdate0> (<htcite0>; <htcite1>), but was already residing in Rio de Janeiro by <htdate1> (<htcite2>). His trajectory in Brazil was not limited to the Southeast region, as shown by the testimony of Father Pedro Leitão in <htdate2>, in Bahia (<htcite3).
According to his testimony in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>)
Rui married Cecilia Roiz, according to the *de genere* of Pedro de Godoy Moreira (<htcite0>), his descendant.
According to his testimony in the canonization process of Saint José de Anchieta (<htcite0>).
Research by Hélio A. Viotti indicates his connection to Rui Dias Machado and his mother, Isabel Afonso (<htcite0>).
According to the *de genere* of Pedro de Godoy Moreira (<htcite0>), his descendant.

The life of Priest Lourenço Dias Machado reinforces the family's ties to the Christian Church in São Paulo.

His work as a clergyman—being the first vicar of São Paulo—is mentioned in several passages of the Records of São Paulo. Among these, a request from the people for him not to leave the city stands out, as well as his position against handing over villages to the Jesuits (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

Besides São Paulo, it is known that the priest was in Bahia in <htdate0> (<htcite2>) and was living in Angra in the year <htdate1> (<htcite3>)

Throughout the centuries, and even today, the desire to trace one's origins to specific groups, thereby avoiding miscegenation, persists in some communities (<htcite0>).

On the other hand, when dealing with different names, it is also impossible to ignore that confusions occur.

The story of Pedro Dias is an example of these genealogical confusions.

#### Initial Proposal

According to Américo de Moura and Luiz Gonzaga da Silva Leme, the Portuguese man Pedro Dias supposedly married an indigenous woman named Maria da Grã, daughter of Chief Tibiriçá, after being a student of the Society of Jesus (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

He lived in Santo André in <htdate0>, but was already in São Paulo by <htdate1>. In the latter city, he performed various jobs, as shown by the Minutes of São Paulo (<htcite2>).

#### A Love Story

When publishing the *História da Companhía de Jesus*, Priest Serafim Leite provides information that contradicts the initial narrative.

According to the priest, in <htdate2> he was in Bahia *"...Bro. Pero Dias still a novice, born here in this land"*, but he was no longer on the list of brothers in <htdate3> (<htcite3>). With this information, we are led to the conclusion that he was not born in Portugal, but in Bahia, Brazil.

His birth is not the only point addressed by Priest Serafim Leite. His work also provides data about a love story that cannot be ignored (<htcite4>):

• "Pedro Dias was a lay brother of the Society of Jesus and could not marry, but such was the sympathy the native people felt for him and such was Tibiriçá's insistence on having him as a son-in-law that he, having obtained the necessary dispensation from his vow, married Princess Terebé, who was baptized Maria and took the surname da Grã out of respect for Father Luiz da Grã of the Society of Jesus."

Reflection 4: Are they the same people?

The dates show that the person described by Priest Serafim Leite is consistent with the one described by Américo de Moura.
For the period when the data was collected in Bahia, no minutes survived in São Paulo.

Are we, therefore, talking about the same people?

#### Deepening the Research

H. V. Castro Coelho provides data about a play in which a "Pedro Dias" was the main character, played by the same Pedro Dias mentioned in the initial proposal (<htcite0>).

Another important piece of information, found in a footnote, states that no dispensation for a Pedro Dias was found in the Society of Jesus documents (<htcite1>).

#### Conclusions

Regarding the report of the marriage to a supposed daughter of Tibiriçá, it is possible to state that there is no proof. Late genealogies cannot be considered evidence for these events.

Similarly, it is not possible to infer whether they are exactly the same people, as there are no documents in São Paulo from the period when there is a record of a Brother Pedro Dias in Bahia.

Thus, we can—cautiously—separate the facts documented in the minutes from the doubts that remain in both lines of research, as well as recognize that it is impossible to state who his first wife was.

This text will not detail the generations of Pedro Dias and his wives. We recommend searching for documents that can validate the works mentioned here.

Late genealogies and H. V. Castro Coelho mention that he had children before marrying Antonia Gomes; therefore, he must have had a prior relationship with another person (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

We have created this person profile taking into account the poem mentioned by Father Serafim Leite, which contradicts the idea presented in the late genealogies (<htcite2>).
Mentioned in late genealogies and by H. V. Castro Coelho (<htcite0>; <htcite1>).

#### What is a *devassa*?

The relationship between the Church and the State allowed the Portuguese government to exercise control over extensive land areas, such as the Brazilian territory.

An example of this control were the *devassas*. While studying the devassas in Minas Gerais, André Nogueira defines them, citing Figueiredo and Boschi (<htcite0>):

• "devassas can be defined as a type of religious repression practice that is simpler and in many ways more immediate and summary, although carried out in two stages: initially the crimes and deviations were identified, with the collected cases being taken to the bishop's seat to be judged, and subsequently the designated visitors returned to the visited areas to apply the punishments"
Little is known about him. It is only possible to state that he was an indigenous man murdered in prison (<htcite0>).

What we know about Bento Dias is presented mainly in population maps of Cachoeira do Campo (<htcite0>).

However, documents related to the owners of the farms where he and his wife lived allow us to propose a possible path for part of his life.

#### *Agregados*

Imperial Brazilian society was composed of different social groups. Beyond the figure of the emperor, the large landowners, and the enslaved people, there was also a generic group called “agregados“.

The definition of “agregado” is quite broad, with different meanings over time (<htcite0>). In the context of this text, we are possibly dealing with a free person who resided on lands granted by the owner, in exchange for work (<htcite1>). However, the hypothesis that they could also be descendants of someone who had been enslaved is not ruled out.

#### A Possible Dependent Family

The Population Map of Cachoeira do Campo from the year <htdate0>, in *Fogo 10*, lists among the dependent families a white woman, D. Luiza, living alongside free "pardos" (mixed-race) and "crioulos" (Brazilian-born individuals of African descent). Among these people is Bento Dias, our character. They all resided on the property of Anna Theodora Pimenta (<htcite2>).

When observing the free "pardo" people, it is noticeable that most signed with the surname Dias, with an age difference of about 11 years between the oldest and the youngest. This fact leads us to suppose that we are, possibly, looking at the same family (<htcite3>).

#### Change

The year <htdate0> became an important milestone in Bento Dias's life. That year, Dona Anna Theodora Pimenta da Silva wrote her will (<htcite0>), possibly passing away soon after. In this document, we are informed that one of the people responsible for her assets was Maria Ursulla, who lived in *Fogo 10* (household) of the <htdate1> Population Map (<htcite1>).

The fact that Maria Ursulla became responsible for the assets had direct consequences for Bento's life. In the <htdate2>, population map, it is observed that he was living in Dona Maria Ursulla's house, already married to Anastacia, who had been freed since the last record. Both worked in the residence as a tailor and seamstress, respectively (<htcite2>).

#### News

By <htdate3>, it is clear that the life of Bento Dias and his family continued to progress. In a new population map, he no longer lived as a dependent in Dona Maria Ursulla's house—he now had his own *Fogo*, number 83.

Other changes are also observed (<htcite3>):
- Bento Dias begins to adopt the surname Silva, common to the two women who had taken him in;
- He is identified as a tailor;
- His wife appears for the first time with devotional surnames: Maria de Jesus;
- The family grows: the couple has four children.

Bento Dias (da Silva) is mentioned again in an <htdate4>, document, when he appears to receive a "terça" (a third, likely a portion of an inheritance) donated to his wife as an inheritance (<htcite4>).
According to their son's baptism record (<htcite0>).
As per his baptism on <htdate0> (<htcite0>).

exercise_v2.question: Existe uma única família Dias?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Não há qualquer possibilidade de fazer conexão a uma única pessoa para as famílias Dias, pois o sobrenome é oriundo de um patronímico.

exercise_v2.question: Todas as indígenas brasileiras assinando Dias descendem de Isabel Dias?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: Não é possível fazer este tipo de afirmação. Além do mais, conforme documentos e exames genéticos demonstram, Beatriz Dias não é filha de Isabel Dias.

exercise_v2.question: Biologia e matemática fazem parte do estudo da genealogia?
exercise_v2.additionalInfo: A genética tem sido parte importante no estudo da genealogia. Estudar genética implica em utilizar a matemática, a fim de estimar as populações. Desta forma, todas as ciências juntas colaboram para o estudo da genealogia.
